questions.text:
A 69-year-old man with metastatic colon cancer is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath, fever, chills, and a productive cough with streaks of blood for the past 5 days. He has a history of emphysema. The patient does not have abdominal pain or headache. He receives chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin every 6 weeks; his last cycle was 3 weeks ago. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. A few scattered inspiratory crackles are heard over the right lung. His mucous membranes are dry. Cardiac examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.3 mg/dL


Leukocyte count
700/mm3


Segmented neutrophils
68%


Lymphocytes
25%


Eosinophils
4%


Monocytes
3%


Platelet count
104,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
75 mg/dL


 Urea nitrogen
41 mg/dL


 Creatinine
2.1 mg/dL


 Galactomannan antigen

Positive


Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can be used to treat Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which should always be considered in an immunosuppressed patient with cough, fever, and hypoxia. However, the presence of galactomannan antigen suggests aspergillosis, a fungal infection for which TMP-SMX is ineffective.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin is commonly used for the empiric therapy of community-acquired pneumonia in patients with comorbidities (e.g., malignancy). While this patient's productive cough and fever are concerning for pneumonia, he is neutropenic and the presence of galactomannan antigen in the serum suggests aspergillosis, necessitating a different therapy strategy.

C) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin-tazobactam, a beta-lactam antibiotic with anti-pseudomonas activity, is commonly used for the empiric therapy of healthcare-associated pneumonia if risk factors for resistant pathogens or Pseudomonas infection are present. However, while this patient is at risk of Pseudomonas infection (given his structural lung disease and neutropenia), the presence of galactomannan antigen suggests aspergillosis, a fungal infection for which piperacillin-tazobactam is ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of levofloxacin with a late-generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime can be used as empiric therapy for patients with pneumonia and risk factors for Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. Although this patient is at risk of Pseudomonas infection (given his structural lung disease and neutropenia), the presence of galactomannan antigen is suggestive of aspergillosis, a fungal infection for which neither ceftazidime nor levofloxacin is effective.

E) INCORRECT:

A combination of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is used to treat Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can also present with hemoptysis, dyspnea, and fever. This patient's neutropenia and pre-existing lung disease are also risk factors for active pulmonary tuberculosis. However, the acute clinical presentation and the positive serum galactomannan antigen are suggestive of aspergillosis.

F) INCORRECT:

In a patient with invasive aspergillosis, echinocandins such as caspofungin are only indicated if first-line therapy fails. Although this patient's neutropenia and presence of galactomannan antigen are suggestive of invasive aspergillosis, an alternate treatment regimen is more appropriate.

G) CORRECT:

Intravenous voriconazole is usually the drug of choice for the treatment of invasive aspergillosis, a serious fungal infection that typically involves the respiratory tract. Treatment should be initiated empirically if invasive aspergillosis is strongly suspected, as the infection has a very high mortality rate. Diagnosis is confirmed by bronchoalveolar lavage and/or biopsy with histopathological identification of septate hyphae branching dichotomously at 45° angles. Liposomal amphotericin B can be used as an alternative if the patient has hepatic dysfunction or hypersensitivity to voriconazole. Drugs such as caspofungin, micafungin, and posaconazole can be used as salvage therapy if first-line therapy fails.
questions.hint: The presence of galactomannan antigen in the serum of a patient with hemoptysis, dyspnea, and fever suggests invasive aspergillosis. Immunosuppression (in this case, due to bone marrow suppression by 5-fluorouracil) and pre-existing lung disease (e.g., emphysema) are important risk factors for aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a productive cough with brownish sputum and shortness of breath on exertion. During this period, he has also had a 5-kg (11 lb) weight loss despite no change in appetite. He has not had fever or night sweats. Three years ago, he was treated for pulmonary tuberculosis for 6 months. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include metoprolol, aspirin, rosuvastatin, enalapril, and antiretroviral therapy. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He lives in California and has not traveled in the last 6 months. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 138/92 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows inspiratory crackles at the right infraclavicular area. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,300/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 38 mm/h. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 490/mm3. X-rays of the chest in the upright position and right lateral decubitus are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection are at increased risk of developing reactivation tuberculosis, which can manifest with productive cough, shortness of breath, weight loss, and cavitary lung lesions. However, an intracavitary mass that shifts position when the patient moves is not expected in tuberculosis. Moreover, patients with reactivation tuberculosis typically present with fever and night sweats.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view; insert: axial CT, lung window) of a patient with postprimary tuberculosis

A thick-walled irregularly shaped cavity (green overlay) in the left lung apex is surrounded by micronodular opacities (examples indicated by dotted lines), which are better seen on the CT image than on the chest radiograph.

The differential diagnosis for a cavitary lung lesion includes both infectious (bacterial, fungal, and occasionally parasitic) and noninfectious (malignant, inflammatory, vascular, and traumatic) etiologies. In postprimary tuberculosis, the apicoposterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes are common sites of involvement. A thick-walled cavity accompanied by consolidation or nodular opacities can signify active disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection are at increased risk of developing histoplasmosis, which can manifest with weight loss and pulmonary symptoms. Cavitary lung lesions are rare, however, and the most common x-ray findings include diffuse, interstitial infiltrates, and hilar lymphadenopathy, none of which are seen here. Moreover, this patient has no history of traveling to endemic areas (e.g., the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys).

C) INCORRECT:

Lung adenocarcinoma can manifest with productive cough, shortness of breath, and weight loss, and a pulmonary mass is usually seen on chest x-ray. However, an intracavitary mass that shifts position when the patient moves is not expected; this finding is suggestive of a different condition.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (A: PA view) and CT chest (B: coronal plane; lung window) of a patient with pulmonary adenocarcinoma

A spiculated nodule is seen in the upper lobe of the right lung (white arrows).

RULB = Right upper lobe bronchus

D) CORRECT:

This patient's x-ray findings are consistent with an aspergilloma, one of the forms of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA). Aspergillus colonizes preexisting cavities and forms a fungal ball, which is not attached to the surrounding tissue and can, therefore, be moved by repositioning the patient. CPA is most commonly seen in individuals who are immunocompromised (e.g., due to HIV infection) and those with previous pulmonary pathologies, especially cavitary lung disease (e.g., resulting from tuberculosis). CPA can manifest with shortness of breath, cough, hemoptysis, as well as constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and fatigue. Positive serology for Aspergillus IgG antibodies is crucial to establish the diagnosis. CPA should be treated with itraconazole or voriconazole, and surgical resection is indicated in patients with aspergilloma.

E) INCORRECT:

Lung abscesses can manifest with productive cough with brownish sputum, shortness of breath, and weight loss, and an intraparenchymal cavity is usually seen on chest x-ray. However, patients with lung abscesses are usually acutely ill and present with high fever, chills, and night sweats. Moreover, an intracavitary air-fluid level rather than a mobile mass would be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung abscess

A large thick-walled (green overlay) cavity projecting over the perihilar region of the right lung contains an air-fluid level (indicated by red line).

The differential for this appearance includes abscess (bacterial, mycobacterial, fungal), cavitary noninfectious granuloma, and cavitary malignant lesion.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection are at increased risk of developing pneumocystis pneumonia, which can manifest with a gradual onset of cough, shortness of breath, and weight loss. However, chest x-ray typically shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region rather than a mobile, intracavitary mass. Moreover, this condition is more common in patients with a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 200/mm3.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)

Bilateral opacification of the lungs is visible in a perihilar (bat wing or butterfly) distribution (green overlay). This pattern of involvement can be seen in a variety of diseases, including pulmonary edema (cardiogenic and noncardiogenic), pneumonia, inhalational lung injury, pulmonary hemorrhage, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, and malignancy. Low lung volumes and cardiac silhouette enlargement, which may accompany cardiogenic edema, are not present on this radiograph.

Bilateral perihilar opacification is a common presentation of PCP pneumonia and may have a granular, reticular, or airspace appearance on chest radiography. PCP may also present with lung cysts and pneumothorax. A ground-glass appearance is commonly described on CT. Nodules, cavities, lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusions are uncommon.
questions.hint: The chest x-rays show a mass that shifts position whenever the patient is repositioned.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever, chills, shortness of breath, chest pain, and a productive cough with bloody sputum for the past several days. He has metastatic pancreatic cancer and is currently undergoing polychemotherapy. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). Pulmonary examination shows scattered inspiratory crackles in all lung fields. A CT scan of the chest shows multiple nodules, cavities, and patchy areas of consolidation. A photomicrograph of a specimen obtained on pulmonary biopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis causes tuberculosis (TB) and primarily affects the lungs. Active TB can present with fever, chest pain, dyspnea, productive cough, hemoptysis, and cavitation on chest CT, as seen in this patient. Moreover, immunodeficiency (in this case, due to chemotherapy) is a risk factor for both primary and reactivation TB. However, pulmonary biopsy would show acid-fast bacilli with caseating granulomas and not hyphae characteristic of fungi.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)

The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's pulmonary biopsy findings are diagnostic of infection with Aspergillus fumigatus. Immunosuppression (in this case, due to chemotherapy) is an important risk factor for invasive aspergillosis, a potentially life-threatening condition that most commonly affects the lungs and presents with hemoptysis, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and fever, as seen in this patient. The galactomannan antigen immunoassay is increasingly used for diagnosis. Treatment with IV voriconazole should be initiated immediately.

Aspergillus can spread hematogenously from the lungs to all organs (e.g., heart, kidney, liver, eyes). Disseminated infection is associated with very high mortality.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

There are diffuse reticulonodular opacities in both lungs with numerous larger nodules interspersed throughout (examples indicated by red rectangle). In the upper zone of the right lung, an ovoid lesion can be seen that is surrounded by a thin rim with normal radiolucency (arrowheads).

This finding is known as the air crescent sign and is characteristic of aspergilloma.

C) INCORRECT:

Histoplasma capsulatum can cause pulmonary histoplasmosis, which manifests with mild fever, chills, chest pain, and, multiple nodular lesions on chest CT, as in this patient. However, if present, cough is usually nonproductive and hemoptysis is uncommon. Although immunosuppression (e.g., due to chemotherapy, as in this case) is a risk factor for infection with histoplasmosis after exposure to contaminated soil, this patient's lung biopsy findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis as a silver stain examination would show macrophages filled with dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a soil specimen at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)

Numerous septated hyphae are visible throughout the image. The large, knobbly (tuberculated), dark blue spherical structures are the macroconidia. The small, smooth, pink spherical structures are the microconidia.

This is the typical appearance of Histoplasma capsulatum in mold (mycelial) form. At temperatures > 37°C, Histoplasma capsulatum exists in a yeast form.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic fungal lung infection presenting with dry cough, progressive dyspnea, and low-grade fever. Although it occurs almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals like this patient, his clinical presentation, chest CT, and pulmonary biopsy are inconsistent with this diagnosis. Imaging of PCP typically shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region, and a histopathological exam with methenamine silver staining would visualize disc-shaped P. jirovecii cysts with central spores.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of alveolar tissue infected with P. jirovecii (Grocott's methenamine silver stain, high magnification)

The cysts of this fungus are located within the alveoli together with an inflammatory exudate (red overlay). The cyst walls are stained black in this silver stain.

E) INCORRECT:

Rhizopus oryzae causes mucormycosis, a rare, life-threatening fungal infection that affects immunocompromised and diabetic patients. Pulmonary mucormycosis rapidly progresses and causes extensive necrosis and infarction, with potential spread to the mediastinum and heart. Most patients present with fever and hemoptysis, as seen in this case. However, unlike this patient's histopathologic findings, a lung biopsy would reveal broad, nonseptate hyphae with right-angle branching.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a maxillary sinus biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Broad, nonseptate hyphae with right-angle branching are visible (example indicated by green overlay). These are accompanied by numerous neutrophils indicating acute sinusitis.

This is the typical appearance of mucormycosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, a systemic fungal infection most commonly affecting the lungs. Blastomycosis can present with fever, productive cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain, as seen in this patient. Chest CT may show nodules and areas of consolidation with cavitation. However, a lung biopsy would show characteristic yeast forms with broad-based buds. Extrapulmonary manifestations of blastomycosis most commonly involve the skin (e.g., papules, nodules, verrucous lesions).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

G) INCORRECT:

Inhalation of Cryptococcus neoformans can cause pulmonary cryptococcosis. While infection is usually mild or asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals, patients that are immunosuppressed (e.g., due to chemotherapy, as in this case) are at increased risk for both symptomatic disease and hematogenous dissemination (i.e., cryptococcosis). Pulmonary cryptococcosis can present with productive cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and fever, as seen in this patient. However, unlike this patient's lung biopsy findings, a histopathologic examination would show pleomorphic, round/oval yeasts with narrow-necked budding.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (Mucicarmine stain; medium power magnification)

Numerous ovoid yeasts of varying size with thick capsules (stained red to violet), some showing narrow-based budding (examples indicated by arrowheads), can be found within the alveoli.

This appearance suggests infection with Cryptococcus neoformans.

H) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is most commonly associated with skin and mucosal infection (candidiasis). In immunocompetent individuals, Candida usually causes minor localized infections, including thrush, candida vulvovaginitis, and infections of intertriginous areas of the skin. More widespread and systemic infections may occur in immunocompromised individuals, as this patient. However, Candida-associated pneumonia is extremely rare. Moreover, biopsy of the involved tissue would show a budding yeast with nonseptate hyphae.
Image Description:

Grocott's methenamine silver staining (~ 120x magnification) of lung tissue contaminated with Candida albicans (black).

Candida albicans is dimorphic: It can appear either as oval/round or filamentous. The filamentous, elongated form of Candida albicans (pseudohyphal form) is more pathogenic than the oval/round form (blastospore). Transition from blastospore to filament can occur. Candida albicans can also form true hyphae, which may sometimes be found in invasive candidiasis but are not shown here.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph of this patient's pulmonary biopsy shows narrow septate hyphae branching dichotomously at 45°. A galactomannan antigen detection assay would likely be positive in this patient's serum.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of cough productive of yellow sputum with occasional streaks of blood. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis. He is afebrile. Pulmonary examination shows inspiratory crackles at the left infraclavicular area. An x-ray of his chest shows a radiopaque mass in the left upper lung lobe that shifts upon repositioning. A sputum sample does not grow acid-fast bacteria despite multiple cultures. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hypersensitivity reaction is the underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). This condition occurs as a result of chronic exposure to Aspergillus. Individuals with ABPA commonly present with symptoms of sinusitis and often have a history of cystic fibrosis or asthma, neither of which is the case here. Furthermore, a mass on lung imaging that moves with repositioning would not be expected in the case of ABPA.

B) INCORRECT:

Invasive aspergillosis, which manifests with severe pneumonia, septicemia, and extrapulmonary involvement, is most often seen in immunocompromised patients. This patient's presentation is comparatively mild and his history does not suggest an immunocompromised state, making an invasive infection unlikely. Moreover, his history of pulmonary tuberculosis and chest x-ray findings point to a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is a type of lung disease that is caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, which usually occurs in the course of occupational exposure. Patients with asbestosis commonly present with exertional dyspnea, dry cough, and a chest x-ray showing diffuse bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, none of which are present here. Moreover, this patient has no history of asbestos exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic transformation of cells in the lung can result in several different types of lung cancer. Individuals with lung carcinomas may present with blood-tinged sputum and cough, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features commonly associated with lung neoplasms, such as weight loss, shortness of breath, wheezing, and a history of smoking. Given the movable intracavitary mass seen on this patient's chest x-ray (in contrast to the rigid mass usually seen in lung cancers) and his history of pulmonary tuberculosis, he most likely has a different condition.

E) CORRECT:

Opportunistic colonization of a heavily scarred lung cavity (e.g., after a bout of pulmonary tuberculosis) by Aspergillus species describes the pathogenesis of aspergilloma. Aspergilloma (also known as a fungus ball) can manifest with cough, hemoptysis, and a radiopaque mass that shifts upon repositioning, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

An elongated homogeneous mass in right right upper lobe represents an aspergilloma (green overlay) within a cavitary lung lesion. Air is present between the aspergilloma and the thin wall (dashed outline) of the cavity. A thin crescent of air is seen along the sides of the aspergilloma, whereas a larger collection of air is seen above it.

Other findings on this radiograph include large lung volumes, small dense pulmonary nodules that are likely calcified (examples indicated by arrowheads), and a possible mass (circle) projecting over right lower lobe pulmonary vessels.

The term “air crescent sign” is sometimes applied to air that may accompany an aspergilloma, cavitary malignancy, lung abscess, or other entity. However, the term is most commonly used to describe air between devitalized lung tissue and surrounding parenchyma in the setting of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with lung abscesses can present with a productive cough and blood-tinged sputum. However, most patients present acutely and have a fever, neither of which is the case here. Moreover, the classic plain film finding in lung abscess is a discrete collection with an air-fluid level. This patient's chest x-ray instead shows an intracavitary radiopaque mass that moves on repositioning.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features (productive cough, hemoptysis), history of tuberculosis, and intracavitary mass on chest x-ray suggest chronic pulmonary aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for evaluation of recurrent episodes of productive cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath over the past month. Physical examination shows coarse crackles and expiratory wheezing over both lung fields. Serum studies show elevated levels of IgE and eosinophilia. A CT scan of the lungs shows centrally dilated bronchi with thickened walls and peripheral airspace consolidation. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. One week later, the patient continues to show deterioration in lung function. A sputum culture is most likely to grow which of the following?

choices.text: Monomorphic, septate hyphae that branch at acute angles
Monomorphic, broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at wide angles

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dimorphic, broad-based budding yeasts are characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis, which causes blastomycosis. In immunocompetent individuals, blastomycosis typically manifests as acute or chronic pneumonia and, especially in immunocompromised individuals, extrapulmonary symptoms (e.g., verrucous skin and lytic bone lesions). Blastomycosis is not typically associated with cystic fibrosis. Furthermore, this patient's bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels are not consistent with Blastomyces dermatitidis infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of skin tissue sample (PAS stain)

Two large cells with thick walls are visible in the center of the image (green overlay). There is a single, broad-based area of contact between the two cells. These are budding Blastomyces dermatitidis yeast cells. The yeast cells are surrounded by numerous neutrophils.

Thick-walled fungi with single, broad-based buds are characteristic features of the yeast form of Blastomyces dermatitidis at body temperature (37°C). At room temperature (∼23°C), Blastomyces dermatitidis exists in a mold form.

B) CORRECT:

Monomorphic, septate hyphae branching at acute angles are characteristic of Aspergillus fumigatus, the causative organism in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. ABPA most commonly affects patients with cystic fibrosis or severe asthma. Small and ubiquitous spores of Aspergillus easily reach the alveoli where they trigger a chronic and complex hypersensitivity reaction, primarily due to poor mucociliary clearance. Symptoms of ABPA include wheezing, chronic cough, and shortness of breath. Imaging most often shows evidence of central bronchiectasis, as seen in this patient. ABPA is treated with glucocorticoids and itraconazole.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; medium power magnification)

There are numerous elongated, septated hyphae (examples indicated by blue overlay) of uniform diameter and with dichotomous branching at approx. 45° angles.

This is the typical appearance of Aspergillus. A culture is required to determine the exact Aspergillus species.

C) INCORRECT:

Dimorphic, cigar-shaped budding yeast may be seen in tissue samples from patients infected with Sporothrix schenckii, which causes sporotrichosis. Sporotrichosis most often presents as an ulcer at the site of recent skin trauma (classically, a prick from a rose thorn) that progresses to ascending lymphangitis. Pulmonary sporotrichosis is exceedingly rare and manifests as single or multiple cavitary lesions in immunocompromised patients. Bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels would not be expected.
Image Description:

Microscopy of a fungal culture at 25°C (lactophenol cotton blue stain)
Culture specimen obtained from a skin ulcer.

Numerous septated hyphae are seen.
Oval spores (conidia) are connected to the hyphae with narrow stems.
The buds are arranged in rosette-like clusters at the tips of the hyphae.

This is the typical appearance of the mold (mycelial) form of the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
(At body temperature or temperatures > 37°C, Sporothrix schenckii exists in a yeast form, with characteristic cigar-shaped yeast cells.)

D) INCORRECT:

Monomorphic, narrow budding encapsulated yeast are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a pathogenic fungus that can cause pneumonia in immunodeficient patients (e.g., those with AIDS). Cryptococcosis would be very unusual in a pediatric patient with cystic fibrosis. Furthermore, bronchiectasis, eosinophilia, and elevated serum IgE levels would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Monomorphic, broad, nonseptate hyphae that branch at wide angles are characteristic of Mucor and/or Rhizopus, two genera of molds that are ubiquitous in decaying vegetation and soil. The classic presentation of infection with these organisms is a rapidly progressive, necrotizing infection of the nose and face in a diabetic patient. Pulmonary mucormycosis is also possible and manifests in immunocompromised individuals with symptoms of pneumonia. Imaging may show a solitary nodule, cavitary lesion, or an area of consolidation but not bronchiectasis. Furthermore, elevated serum levels of IgE and eosinophilia would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a maxillary sinus biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Broad, nonseptate hyphae with right-angle branching are visible (example indicated by green overlay). These are accompanied by numerous neutrophils indicating acute sinusitis.

This is the typical appearance of mucormycosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Dimorphic, budding yeast with pseudohyphae are microscopic features of candidiasis, which is caused by the fungus Candida albicans. Candidiasis can lead to pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, manifesting with fever, malaise, dyspnea, and cough. The central bronchiectasis (centrally dilated bronchi with thickened walls and peripheral airspace consolidation) seen on this patient's chest imaging, eosinophilia, and elevated levels of serum IgE are not typical of pulmonary candidiasis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (200x magnification)

A cluster of yeast-like cells (arrowhead) is visible in the upper right corner of the image. Arising from this cluster are numerous pseudohyphae identifiable as long filamentous nonseptate structures (example indicated by a blue overlay). Asexual budding spores (blastospores; example indicated by red overlay) arise along the sides of the pseudohyphae. Thick-walled solitary circular chlamydospores (resting stage of Candida; example indicated by green overlay) arise from the tips of the pseudohyphae.

This coexistence of different morphological types (yeast cells, pseudohyphae, budding blastospores, and resting chlamydospores) is typical of Candida albicans.
questions.hint: Failure to respond to antibiotic treatment in a patient with a history of cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary exacerbations, elevated IgE levels, and CT findings of bronchiectasis should raise concern for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with bronchial asthma comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a progressively worsening cough. Initially, the cough occurred 3 or 4 days per week and was nonproductive. Over the past month, the cough has been occurring daily and is accompanied by thick brown sputum that is occasionally blood-tinged. Until 4 months ago, her only medications were inhaled albuterol as needed and daily low-dose inhaled budesonide; 2 months ago, treatment with daily inhaled formoterol was initiated. She does not smoke. She has not traveled recently. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Chest auscultation shows scattered expiratory wheezing in both lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9500/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
57%


 Bands
3%


 Eosinophils

10%


 Basophils
0.5%


 Lymphocytes
26%


 Monocytes
3%


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
45 mm/h


Serum



 Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


 IgE

1120 IU/mL


An x-ray of the chest shows linear opacities in both upper lobes and thickened airways with irregular cystic opacities primarily near the hilar region. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 75% and a FEV1 of 70% of predicted. A tuberculin skin test shows an induration of 3 mm. In addition to the continued use of inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?

choices.text: Oral rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy
Oral prednisone and montelukast sodium therapy
Intravenous methylprednisolone, oral cyclophosphamide and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Most cases of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) affect patients with preexisting structural bronchopulmonary abnormalities, such as bronchial asthma (as seen here) or cystic fibrosis (CF). In patients with bronchial asthma, there should be concern for ABPA if respiratory symptoms worsen despite treatment and features of bronchiectasis (e.g., productive cough with thick brown sputum, thickened airways with irregular cystic opacities on chest x-ray) develop along with an elevated ESR, eosinophilia, and very high concentrations of serum IgE. The first-line therapy for ABPA is an oral glucocorticoid (e.g., prednisone) in combination with itraconazole for several weeks to months. Monotherapy with glucocorticoids may also be considered for the first episode of acute ABPA. The diagnosis of ABPA is confirmed by skin antigen testing or measuring Aspergillus-specific IgE.

B) INCORRECT:

Combined therapy with oral rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is given during the initiation phase of active tuberculosis (TB) infection. This condition often manifests with a subacute or chronic blood-tinged productive cough but this patient's negative tuberculin skin test and x-ray findings make the diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, the patient has no risk factors for exposure to TB (e.g., travel to an endemic country, confirmed TB contacts, homelessness) and no characteristic constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, night sweats). Finally, eosinophilia and elevated IgE levels are not typical features of active TB.

C) INCORRECT:

Therapy with oral prednisone and montelukast is added to the drug regimen for chronic asthma when severe persistent asthma is diagnosed. This patient's daily cough and FEV1 of 75%, however, indicate moderate persistent asthma, for which her current pharmacotherapy is appropriate. Moreover, the chest x-ray and laboratory findings suggest another condition that requires different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Therapy with intravenous methylprednisolone, oral cyclophosphamide, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given to patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA; Churg-Strauss syndrome), which can manifest with exacerbation of asthmatic symptoms, eosinophilia, and elevated IgE levels. However, EGPA also affects the gastrointestinal tract, skin, upper airways, and/or kidneys, and patients typically present with clinical features that reflect the involvement of these organs (e.g., skin nodules, palpable purpura, nasal congestion and/or rhinorrhea, abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and elevated plasma creatinine or hematuria).

E) INCORRECT:

Therapy with oral ivermectin is indicated for helminthic lung infections (e.g., strongyloidiasis, ancylostomiasis, necatoriasis, ascariasis), which can manifest with a dry cough, wheezing, eosinophilia, and elevated IgE levels. This constellation of symptoms is known as Loeffler syndrome. These helminths, however, are prevalent in the tropics and enter the host via the skin (most commonly via the feet) or the fecal-oral route (via contaminated food) whereas this patient has no history of recent travel. Moreover, chest x-ray typically shows multiple oval opacities that can reach up to several centimeters in size in both lung fields rather than the x-ray findings seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Therapy with oral prednisone and azithromycin would be initiated during an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD), which is characterized by an increase in the frequency and severity of cough as well as the volume and purulence of sputum. However, a chest x-ray in a patient with COPD characteristically shows emphysematous changes (e.g., hyperinflated lungs, parenchymal bullae, subpleural blebs) rather than the findings seen here. Moreover, this patient is a nonsmoker, and eosinophilia and elevated IgE levels are not typical of COPD or AECOPD.
questions.hint: An antigen skin test for Aspergillus in this patient would be positive.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man with asthma is hospitalized for a 3-day history of increased shortness of breath. During the past several years, he has been hospitalized multiple times with similar episodes of dyspnea as well as wheezing. He also reports periodically coughing up brown mucus plugs. Each time, he has been treated with oral glucocorticoids to good effect.
On this admission, his current medications include an inhaled glucocorticoid and long-acting beta agonist, as well as albuterol to be used for short-term relief of dyspnea or wheezing.
The patient is afebrile and normotensive. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, his heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 91% while he is breathing ambient air. He has diffuse wheezing. He has no murmur, rub, or jugular venous distention. He has no pedal edema.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. His leukocyte count is 11,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with a normal differential blood count — 47% neutrophils, 32% lymphocytes, and 8% monocytes — except for slightly more eosinophils (13%) than normal (0–8%). The immunoglobulin E level is markedly elevated.
Chest radiograph reveals patchy opacities with central bronchiectasis.
What test is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the rheumatoid factor level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methacholine challenge is not needed in this patient because the diagnosis of asthma has already been established.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventilation-perfusion scanning is useful in determining the presence of thromboembolic disease, which would not manifest as recurrent asthma exacerbations.

C) INCORRECT:

Lung biopsy is not required to make the diagnosis of ABPA; thus, video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery is not indicated.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is concerning for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), which results from colonization of the airways by Aspergillus fumigatus and the subsequent inflammatory response. ABPA occurs in approximately 1% of patients with asthma, typically those with moderate or severe persistent disease.

To make the diagnosis of ABPA, clinicians can apply the following diagnostic criteria from the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology:

• Patients must have a predisposing condition, either asthma or cystic fibrosis.
• Patients must fulfill both obligatory criteria: Elevated levels of total immunoglobulin E (IgE) and either elevated levels of Aspergillus fumigatus (Af)-specific serum IgE or immediate cutaneous reactivity to Af
• Patients must fulfill at least two of the three additional criteria: Radiographic pulmonary opacities consistent with ABPA (central bronchiectasis in the absence of distal bronchiectasis); eosinophilia; and either precipitating serum antibodies to Af or elevated levels of Af-specific serum IgG

In this case, skin testing for Af is the most appropriate next step to secure the diagnosis of ABPA.

Key learning point: The findings of recurrent asthma exacerbations, patchy opacities and central bronchiectasis on chest radiography, eosinophilia, and an elevated immunoglobulin E level are most consistent with a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Connective-tissue diseases can affect the lungs in multiple ways; however, they do not typically cause eosinophilia or elevated IgE levels. Therefore, testing for connective-tissue disorders by means of measuring the rheumatoid factor level (which is detectable in patients with rheumatoid arthritis) is not indicated. Pulmonary manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis most often involve interstitial lung disease, pleural disease, and/or pulmonary nodules; it would be unusual for a patient to present with extraarticular manifestations before experiencing the classic joint symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with long-standing, persistent asthma reports worsening wheezing, cough, and dyspnea during the past month. He has been using high-dose combination inhaled glucocorticoid-long-acting beta2-agonist treatment and inhaled albuterol every 4 hours. Three weeks ago, he started montelukast and oral prednisone 40 mg daily.
Laboratory evaluation reveals an immunoglobulin E level of 2410 IU/mL (reference range, 10–179) and a positive skin test to Aspergillus fumigatus. His leukocyte count before starting treatment with oral glucocorticoids was 9200 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 12% eosinophils (0–8).
CT of the chest shows central bronchiectasis.
Which one of the following medications is most likely to provide clinical improvement for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Worsening wheezing, cough, and dyspnea in a patient with asthma can indicate allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). To make the diagnosis of ABPA, clinicians can apply the following diagnostic criteria from the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology:

• Patients must have a predisposing condition, either asthma or cystic fibrosis.
• Patients must fulfill both obligatory criteria: Elevated levels of total immunoglobulin E (IgE) and either elevated levels of Aspergillus fumigatus-specific serum IgE or immediate cutaneous reactivity to A. fumigatus
• Patients must fulfill at least two of the three additional criteria: Radiographic pulmonary opacities consistent with ABPA (central bronchiectasis in the absence of distal bronchiectasis); eosinophilia; and either precipitating serum antibodies to A. fumigatus or elevated levels of A. fumigatus-specific serum IgG

This patient has a predisposing condition (asthma), he fulfills both obligatory criteria (elevated total IgE levels and a positive skin test to A. fumigatus), and he fulfills two of the three additional criteria based on the CT findings and eosinophilia. Although additional laboratory tests are not necessary to make the diagnosis, it would be reasonable to evaluate for precipitating antibodies to A. fumigatus using double-gel immunodiffusion and for A. fumigatus-specific IgE and IgG antibodies using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.

The mainstay of treatment for ABPA is a high-dose oral glucocorticoid. In patients who are already receiving such treatment, antifungal therapy with itraconazole or voriconazole may improve lung function and exercise tolerance.

Key learning point: In addition to an oral glucocorticoid, the medication that may also be considered for treating allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is itraconazole.

B) INCORRECT:

Theophylline can improve asthma control, but it is not used to treat ABPA.

C) INCORRECT:

Enoxaparin is a low-molecular-weight heparin used in treating pulmonary embolism. Pulmonary embolism is unlikely, given the patient's gradual symptom development, eosinophilia, and other laboratory and imaging findings that suggest a diagnosis of ABPA.

D) INCORRECT:

Ivacaftor is indicated for treating cystic fibrosis, which does not typically manifest with these findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Although methotrexate is used as a glucocorticoid-sparing agent in other diseases, there is no evidence of its benefit in ABPA.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with a history of severe, persistent asthma presents with worsening cough, wheezing, and dyspnea. She reports that her cough produces thick, brown sputum and has not improved despite treatment with moxifloxacin 400 mg by mouth daily for the past 21 days.
Pulmonary function testing demonstrates an FVC of 3.25 liters (predicted value is 3.20 liters), an FEV1 of 1.4 liters (predicted is 2.5), and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 0.43 (predicted is 0.80).
Laboratory testing reveals an absolute eosinophil count of 1200 per mm3 (reference range, 0–350) and a serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) level of 1100 IU/mL (10–179).
CT of the chest is obtained (figures 1 and 2). Aspergillus IgE testing is positive.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumonia is not associated with high IgE levels or eosinophilia.

B) INCORRECT:

Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia is not associated with high IgE levels or eosinophilia.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia is characterized by a marked accumulation of eosinophils in the lung and often manifests as a severe illness with cough, fever, progressive dyspnea, weight loss, wheezing, and night sweats. The finding of bilateral peripheral or pleural-based opacities, described as the “photographic negative of pulmonary edema” is virtually pathognomonic for the disease, if present.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) often present with worsening asthma that is refractory to antibiotics and low-dose oral glucocorticoids. To make the diagnosis of ABPA, clinicians can apply the following diagnostic criteria from the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology:

• Patients must have a predisposing condition, either asthma or cystic fibrosis.
• Patients must fulfill both obligatory criteria: Elevated levels of total immunoglobulin E (IgE) and either elevated levels of Aspergillus fumigatus (Af)-specific serum IgE or immediate cutaneous reactivity to Af
• Patients must fulfill at least two of the three additional criteria: Radiographic pulmonary opacities consistent with ABPA (central bronchiectasis in the absence of distal bronchiectasis); eosinophilia; and either precipitating serum antibodies to Af or elevated levels of Af-specific serum IgG

This patient’s chest CT scans show the presence of bilateral bronchiectasis (figure 1) and bilateral mucous plugging (figure 2). Those findings are consistent with a diagnosis of ABPA.

The mainstay of treatment for ABPA is a high-dose oral glucocorticoid. Antifungal agents such as itraconazole or voriconazole are also used. Notably, high-dose glucocorticoid treatment may suppress peripheral blood eosinophilia and reduce the concentration of total serum IgE and Af-specific precipitating antibodies, making the diagnosis challenging.

Key learning point: The findings of bronchiectasis and severe exacerbations of asthma, together with an elevated serum immunoglobulin E level and blood eosinophilia, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atypical mycobacterial pneumonia is not associated with high IgE levels or eosinophilia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of cough productive of yellow sputum, occasionally streaked with blood. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis. He is afebrile. On pulmonary examination, you hear inspiratory crackles at the left infraclavicular area. A chest x-ray shows a radiopaque mass in the left upper lung lobe that shifts with changes in position. Multiple sputum cultures are negative for acid-fast bacteria. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hypersensitivity reaction is the underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). This condition occurs as a result of chronic exposure to Aspergillus. Individuals with ABPA commonly present with symptoms of sinusitis and often have a history of cystic fibrosis or asthma, neither of which is the case here. Furthermore, a mass on lung imaging that moves with repositioning would not be expected in the case of ABPA.

B) INCORRECT:

Invasive aspergillosis, which manifests with severe pneumonia, septicemia, and extrapulmonary involvement, is most often seen in immunocompromised patients. This patient's presentation is comparatively mild and his history does not suggest an immunocompromised state, making an invasive infection unlikely. Moreover, his history of pulmonary tuberculosis and chest x-ray findings point to a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Neoplastic transformation of cells in the lung can result in several different types of lung cancer. Individuals with lung carcinomas may present with blood-tinged sputum and cough, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features commonly associated with lung neoplasms, such as weight loss, shortness of breath, wheezing, and a history of smoking. Given the movable intracavitary mass seen on this patient's chest x-ray (in contrast to the rigid mass usually seen in lung cancers) and his history of pulmonary tuberculosis, he most likely has a different condition.

D) CORRECT:

Opportunistic colonization of a heavily scarred lung cavity (e.g., after a bout of pulmonary tuberculosis) by Aspergillus species describes the pathogenesis of aspergilloma. Aspergilloma (also known as a fungus ball) can manifest with cough, hemoptysis, and a radiopaque mass that shifts upon repositioning, as seen in this patient.

Key learning point: Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (aspergilloma) develops when Aspergillus opportunistically colonizes preexisting lung cavities, often from prior diseases like tuberculosis, forming a mobile fungus ball visible on imaging.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

An elongated homogeneous mass in right right upper lobe represents an aspergilloma (green overlay) within a cavitary lung lesion. Air is present between the aspergilloma and the thin wall (dashed outline) of the cavity. A thin crescent of air is seen along the sides of the aspergilloma, whereas a larger collection of air is seen above it.

Other findings on this radiograph include large lung volumes, small dense pulmonary nodules that are likely calcified (examples indicated by arrowheads), and a possible mass (circle) projecting over right lower lobe pulmonary vessels.

The term “air crescent sign” is sometimes applied to air that may accompany an aspergilloma, cavitary malignancy, lung abscess, or other entity. However, the term is most commonly used to describe air between devitalized lung tissue and surrounding parenchyma in the setting of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with lung abscesses can present with a productive cough and blood-tinged sputum. However, most patients present acutely and have a fever, neither of which is the case here. Moreover, the classic plain film finding in lung abscess is a discrete collection with an air-fluid level. This patient's chest x-ray instead shows an intracavitary radiopaque mass that moves on repositioning.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical features (productive cough, hemoptysis), history of tuberculosis, and intracavitary mass on chest x-ray suggest chronic pulmonary aspergillosis.
